abstract.para: Learn about the basic concepts of &sudo; and how it works.

topic.para: &sudo; is a Linux command that is used to execute programs as another user. It is the abbreviation for super user do and can be used to run a command as &rootuser; user, means with elevated privileges.

As a normal user on Linux, you have reduced permissions. The &rootuser; user is the Linux superuser and the equivalent to the administrator who has maximum permissions to do anything to the system. Depending on the system configuration, the permissions of the &rootuser; can be restricted.

For security reasons, all &productname; systems separate the normal user from the &rootuser; user. For example, as a normal user, you cannot write to system directories or install programs. Any user with access to the &rootuser; password can gain this privileges and accidentally or maliciously break the system. Therefore it is not recommended to log in as root. A safer approach is logging in as a normal user and running the command prefaced with &sudo; or su to gain root privileges.
Each &productname; system, offers the following options to log in as &rootuser;:

listitem.para: &sudo;: allows you to run a command as &rootuser; and, depending on it's configuration, it may not require the &rootuser; password. All commands executed with su are logged.
su: allows you to run a command as &rootuser; but requires you to know the &rootuser; password. The commands executed with su are not logged.
